newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia Opposition demands pension tax revamp.
newsitem.headline: Australia Opposition demands pension tax revamp.

text.p: Australia's Labor opposition on Tuesday demanded the government revamp its proposed tax surcharge on pension saving funds.

"Labor will not support the Liberals' 15 percent tax on superannuation unless low and middle income earners and retrenched workers are exempted," opposition assistant treasury spokesman Nick Sherry told reporters.

The government said in March it expected the superannuation legislation -- which will bring in an extra A$500 million a year -- to pass the upper house of parliament this month because it believed it had the support of the opposition.
The government needs the support of at least two non-government senators to pass legislation through the Senate.
The goverment plans to levy a tax surcharge of up to 15 percent on superannuation savings for people who earn more than A$70,000 a year or more -- through the surcharge.
The surcharge would be on top of the existing 15 percent tax on contributions.
But Sherry said the reforms would catch up to one million lower income earners who could be pushed above the A$70,000 level by retrenchment payments, insurance payouts or other one-off payments.
The government's position in the Senate has become more precarious with key independent senator Mal Colston pledging on Tuesday to vote against government measures.

A Senate motion needs majority support to pass. If Colston, Labor and other minority parties combine, even if a second independent continues to support Howard's administration, government measures would still be blocked with a 38-38 tied vote.
Sherry said minority parties had not yet declared their position on his planned changes.
